abstract.text: Verify your implementation of In-App Purchases by testing your code throughout its development.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

metadata.title: Testing at all stages of development with Xcode and the sandbox

inlineContent.text: Use the Apple sandbox and Xcode test environments to test your implementation of in-app purchases using the StoreKit framework. Comprehensive testing can help you:
Ensure a seamless purchase flow to provide a positive customer experience in your app.
Implement sound logic that covers all scenarios, such as purchases, restores, and subscription offers.
Validate that purchases behave correctly in production after your app is available in the App Store.
The tools you need to test in-app purchases, non-renewing subscriptions, and auto-renewable subscriptions from early development through beta testing are:
For early development, continuous integration, and debugging. For more information, see
For testing scenarios using in-app purchase data you set up in App Store Connect. For more information, see
For managing beta testing with internal and external testers. TestFlight uses a beta build of your app or App Clip that you upload to App Store Connect. For more information, see
Choose the tools that support the test scenarios you need. Make sure you’re able to perform the setup required for the tools you choose.

During the early stages of development, you may not be ready to configure in-app purchases in App Store Connect. StoreKit Testing in Xcode lets you configure the information locally. You can test StoreKit transactions before you create Sandbox Apple IDs, without a network connection. You can test your app in Simulator or on real devices.

After you set up in-app purchases in App Store Connect, start using the sandbox environment to test the product information your app will use in production. Testing in the sandbox lets you test transactions from end-to-end and from your app to your server. You can also test any server-to-server functionalities your app depends on, such as transaction validation and

TestFlight lets you get feedback from members of your team or from external testers. TestFlight uses the sandbox environment for in-app purchases. Transactions and purchases that occur in the sandbox don’t incur charges. The following table compares the test environments and features:
Provides receipts and JSON Web Signature (JWS) transactions signed by the App Store
Provides subscription renewal information signed by the App Store
None of the test environments charge users when they test buying a product. The App Store doesn’t send emails for purchases or refunds made in the test environments.

To set up and run test scenarios, you often need to control the test environment. For example, you may want to reset a test account to rerun the same test multiple times, or mimic actions users take outside your app that affect the test conditions. The following table shows the capabilities each tool has to control the test environment:
Test different storefronts to affect price tiers and locale
Test subscription upgrades, downgrades, cross-grades, and auto-renew cancellations
Introduce forced StoreKit errors for testing
Speed up or slow down the rate of time for testing subscription renewals
For more information about speeding up renewal periods for testing, see

All apps that offer in-app purchases need to support restoring purchases, displaying in-app purchases to the customer, and handling basic transactions. The following table lists common test scenarios and whether they’re testable in the sandbox or Xcode:
Buy a consumable or non-consumable in-app purchase
Repurchase a non-consumable purchase for repeated testing
Test an interrupted purchase, where the user must complete actions outside the app
Test a failed purchase attempt when payment authorization fails
Retrieve configured in-app purchases from App Store Connect
Yes (optionally); can also retrieve data from a StoreKit configuration file
Manage subscriptions within your app with
Initiate a refund request. For more information, see

content.text: Test subscriptions and Ask to Buy

inlineContent.text: Depending on the in-app purchases your app offers, you may need to test scenarios that involve auto-renewing subscriptions, introductory offers, promotional offers, and Ask to Buy. The following table lists test scenarios and whether they’re testable in the sandbox or Xcode:
Initiate an Ask to Buy transaction that results in a deferred state
Resolve an Ask to Buy transaction by approving or rejecting it
Redeem an introductory offer for an auto-renewable subscription
Redeem a promotional offer for an auto-renewable subscription
Redeem an offer code for an auto-renewable subscription
Process a revoked or refunded subscription
Respond to a customer canceling a subscription and disabling auto-renew
Process a subscription upgrade or downgrade
Process a subscription cross-grade with the same or different duration
Test a price increase for an auto-renewable subscription
Test billing retry and billing grace period

abstract.text: Monitor In-App Purchase events in real time and learn of unreported external purchase tokens, with server notifications from the App Store.
Create and automate tests in Xcode for your app’s subscription and in-app purchase transactions, and SKAdNetwork implementations.
Support In-App Purchases and interactions with the App Store.
Presents the App Store sheet for managing subscriptions.
Notifies the App Store that the app finished processing the transaction.
Indicates to the App Store that the app delivered the purchased content or enabled the service to finish the transaction.
Offer content and services in your app across Apple platforms using a Swift-based interface.
Offer additional content and services in your app using the Original In-App Purchase API.
Test your implementation of In-App Purchases using real product information and server-to-server transactions in the sandbox environment.
Test your introductory pricing in a variety of user scenarios.
Test your app’s implementation of refund requests, and your app’s and server’s handling of approved and declined refunds.
Validate your app’s handling of win-back offers that you configure for the testing environment.
